III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12207 Staff responsibilities
Section • (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be
Description directly responsible for all the following activities:
• (a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home
care. Social service workers shall work directly with
the children, their families, and other relevant
1

individuals and be primarily responsible for the
development, implementation, and review of service
plans for the children and their families.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Foster care worker has not communicated with a relative
interested in placement of a child in care.
Investigation Maternal Grandmother was interviewed via telephone on May
21, 2025. She stated parental rights for Youth A’s parents were
terminated at the end of April 2025 and she would like to be
considered for adoptive placement. Maternal Grandmother stated
Biological Mother was residing with her at the time Youth A was
removed so she was not able to take placement. In addition, she
had some housing issues that needed to be addressed, and her
boyfriend was not in support of Youth A being placed there. She
stated she spoke with Foster Care worker (FCW) sometime at the
end of March 2025 indicating she would like placement of Youth A
but she didn’t have any family support. FCW indicated it was
never too late if she wanted to move forward with being
considered for placement.
She stated Biological Mother reported FCW made a comment to
her while at court for the termination hearing indicating it was too
late for Maternal Grandmother to be considered for placement.
She stated current caregivers already planned to adopt Youth A
and there is a strong attachment between them.
She stated FCW contacted her recently and informed her
someone from an adoption agency would be contacting her to
gather information in order to assess her for possible adoptive
placement.
Foster Care worker (FCW) was interviewed via telephone on
May 21, 2025. She stated she has been the assigned worker
since October 2024. FCW stated at the time she was assigned,
Maternal Grandmother was very forthcoming and indicated she
was not able to care for Youth A due to her work schedule, lack of
support and, primarily because Youth A’s parents were residing
with her. FCW stated she was informed Maternal Grandmother
was contacted at the time Youth A was removed in March 2024
and had indicated she was not able to take placement at that time
for similar reasons. FCW stated other relative options were
explored early on in the case but either were not interested or
were not appropriate for placement of Youth A.
2

FCW stated she spoke with Maternal Grandmother early April
2025. There was discussion about placement of Youth A. FCW
stated she would pass her information along to the assigned
adoption agency if Maternal Grandmother was interested in
placement. She stated there was another discussion with Maternal
Grandmother on April 25, 2025, after the termination hearing took
place and Youth A’s parents released their parental rights. During
that conversation, FCW stated she explained again she would
provide her information to the assigned adoption agency so they
could assess her for possible adoptive placement.
FCW stated she explained to Maternal Grandmother that Youth A
has been in her current placement for over a year and is bonded
with them but clarified she never told her she wouldn’t be
considered for placement or that it was too late in the process to
be considered. She stated she was clear with Maternal
Grandmother the adoption agency would assess any competing
party and make the decision.
FCW stated during conversations with Youth A’s parents they
specifically stated they did not want Youth A to be placed with
Maternal Grandmother. There were concerns regarding Maternal
Grandmother being able to meet Youth A’s needs and Youth A is
bonded to current caregivers.
Foster Care supervisor (FC supervisor) was interviewed via
telephone on May 28, 2025. He stated FCW previously reached
out to Maternal Grandmother to inquire if she was interested in
possible placement of Youth A and she wasn’t able to take her at
that time. He stated Maternal Grandmother had contacted FCW to
inquire about placement mid-April 2025 and that was just prior to
Biological Mother’s releasing her parental rights during a court
hearing on April 22, 2025. He stated the agency felt it was best to
allow the assigned adoption agency to assess Maternal
Grandmother and any other interested parties since the
termination hearing was scheduled for the following week. He
stated they didn’t want to move Youth A and cause any
unnecessary trauma. FC supervisor stated an adoption agency
has been assigned and notified that Maternal Grandmother has
expressed interest in potential adoptive placement. The adoption
agency has indicated they will assess Maternal Grandmother.
Biological Mother was interviewed via telephone on May 28,
2025. She stated Youth A has been in the same placement with
unrelated licensed caregivers since she was 3 months old. She
stated just prior to her releasing her parental rights, Maternal
3

Grandmother expressed interest in placement of Youth A. She
stated she reported to both Maternal Grandmother and FCW she
didn’t think that was a good idea because Youth A was
comfortable and bonded with her current placements.
During the last court hearing when Biological Mother released her
parental rights she stated FCW hinted, but did not directly state,
Maternal Grandmother would be unlikely to obtain placement and
it was too late in the process. She was asked to elaborate on what
she meant by hinted but was unable to provide an example or any
other details. Biological Mother stated she expressed concern to
FCW regarding Maternal Grandmother obtaining placement of
Youth A due to her work schedule, ongoing household
responsibilities and not being realistic about what it would take to
raise Youth A and meet her needs. Biological Mother reported
Maternal Grandmother has previously informed her FCW told her
she could be an option for placement. FCW reported to Biological
Mother the adoption worker will access anyone who expresses
interest in potential adoptive placement.
Documents reviewed:
• Youth A’s MISACWIS case file. April 11, 2025, social
work contact: Maternal Grandmother called the FCW
inquiring about "getting guardianship of Youth A". FCW
informed Maternal Grandmother that Youth A is in a stable
placement. If termination of parental rights occurs, she is
able to ask for an adoption home study through the
adoption worker.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance. Based on completed
interviews and review of Youth A’s MISACWIS case record,
Maternal Grandmother had reported she was unable to take
placement of Youth A for the majority of the case. In early April
2025, just prior to biological parents releasing their parental rights,
Maternal Grandmother notified FCW of her interest in placement
of Youth A. FCW explained she would pass along her information
to the assigned adoption agency who would assess her
household.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
4

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
